mxCell.value:
Simple Past

The simple past tense shows that you are talking about something that has already happened. Unlike the past continuous tense, which is used to talk about past events that happened over a period of time, the simple past tense emphasizes that the action is finished.

Wolfgang admired the way the light glinted off his silver medal.

was + adjective
Wolfgang was proud of his hula hoop victory.
was + noun
The contest was the highlight of his week.

You can also use the simple past to talk about a past state of being, such as the way someone felt about something. This is often expressed with the simple past tense of the verb to be (was) and an adjective, noun, or prepositional phrase.
<font color="#000000">now</font>
<font color="#000000">Future</font>
<font color="#000000">Past</font>
After 2 years, we moved to another town
I was born in 1997 in Minsk

Historical context
(adverb phrase of time) such as
yesterday, or a date or time
examples:
 - 1997 (exact date)
 - After x years (month, days, ...)
 - Next (sequential events)
Then my friend was drafted into the army
Next I was surprised about it
For regular verbs, add -ed to the root form of the verb (or just -d if the root form already ends in an e):

There are some exceptions.. Irregular verbs :(
You just need to remember them
<font color="#000000">Future</font>
<font color="#000000">Past</font>
From Sunday to yesterday, I was in the hospital
<font color="#000000">Sunday</font>
<font color="#000000">Yesterday</font>
<font color="#000000">Date range</font>
<font color="#000000">now</font>

Progressive form

Both of the events in each sentence are "historic", but one took place while another longer-lasting situation was true
<font color="#000000">Future</font>
<font color="#000000">Past</font>
<font color="#000000">now</font>
He noticed strange noise while he was driving
<font style="font-size: 16px" color="#000000">he noticed strange noise somewhere here</font>
I was laugh because of these funny memes
<font color="#000000">Future</font>
<font color="#000000">Past</font>
<font color="#000000">now</font>

Used to, would 

Used to can describe terminated action in the past which is not repeated anymore
would can describe finished habit in the past
I would skateboard almost every day when I was a kid
skateboarding habit
Our factories used to produce more carbon dioxide than now
finished skateboarding
less CO2

Simple Present

The simple present is a verb tense with two main uses. We use the simple present tense when an action is happening right now, or when it happens regularly (or unceasingly, which is why it’s sometimes called present indefinite). Depending on the person, the simple present tense is formed by using the root form or by adding ‑s or ‑es to the end.
<font color="#000000">now</font>
<font color="#000000">Future</font>
<font color="#000000">Past</font>
The other is to talk about habitual actions or occurrences.
He works in the NASA
This group of scientists travels the world every year
they traveled last year
high probability of travelling this year and in the future
"Do not be sorry, be better!" (c) Kratos
Negation: The formula for making a simple present verb negative is do/does + not + [root form of verb]. You can also use the contraction don't or doesn't instead of do not or does not.
<font color="#000000">To make the verb to be negative, the formula is </font><font color="#cc0000">[to be] + not.</font>

"And I see
Huge walls of trees
Huge walls of ice shelves
It takes my breath away" (c) Motorama (Alps)
Please, don't be afraid. CIA agency doesn't care about a song you downloaded last night from the pirate bay
The formula for asking a question in the simple present is do/does + [subject] + [root form of verb].

- How much does it cost? 
- Nobody knows because it's an ancient artifact

- Do you afraid of zombies? 
- No because they are not exist

Fortunately, there is a formula for making simple past verbs negative, and it’s the same for both regular and irregular verbs (except for the verb to be). The formula is did not + [root form of verb]. You can also use the contradiction didn’t instead of did not.
For the verb to be, you don’t need the auxiliary did. When the subject of the sentence is singular, use was not or wasn’t. When the subject is plural, use were not or weren’t.

- Did Ivan change his employment contract yesterday?
- No, he didn't change it. He decided to work night-shift as usual
The formula for asking a question in the simple past tense is did + [subject] + [root form of verb].
- Was it really me? I asked myself while they was showing me old photos
When asking a question with the verb to be, you don’t need the auxiliary did. The formula is was/were + [subject].
"I was there 3000 years ago.." (c) Erlond

Simple Future

The simple future is a verb tense that’s used to talk about things that haven’t happened yet.

"Run away, run away, I'll attack
Run away, run away, go change yourself
Run away, run away, now I'll attack
